title: 107_s1414
content: The "Parent and Teacher Achievement Act of 2001" is cited as the short title. It includes state incentives for teacher testing and merit pay, amending Title II of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Secretary will award funds to states that test teachers every 3 to 5 years, have a merit-based compensation system, and require continuing education credits for recertification. Funding is 50% of the excess appropriation over 2001, capped at $600,000,000. States eligible for awards under this section will receive funding based on the total amount available and the number of eligible states. The funds can be used for activities outlined in section 2207, and the definition of "State" includes all 50 states and the District of Columbia. The effective date for these amendments is October 1, 2001. SEC. 3 allows states to use federal education funds for teacher testing or merit pay programs. SEC. 4 introduces a nonrefundable credit for elementary and secondary school expenses in the Internal Revenue Code. The tax code allows for a credit against taxes for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses up to $1000 per qualifying student, with a limit of $500 for tuition expenses. A qualifying student is defined as a dependent or relative enrolled in school full-time. The tax code allows for a credit against taxes for qualified education expenses. A taxpayer can elect to not apply this credit for any taxable year. The tax code provides a credit for contributions made for elementary and secondary schools, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. The tax code allows a credit of 75% of qualified charitable contributions for the taxable year, with a maximum credit of $500 for individuals ($1,000 for joint returns) and $100,000 for corporations. Qualified charitable contributions refer to cash donations to school tuition organizations. The tax code allows a credit for qualified charitable contributions to organizations that allocate at least 90% of income to school scholarships for students eligible for free or reduced-cost lunch. No double benefit deduction is allowed for contributions eligible for the credit. The tax code allows a credit for qualified charitable contributions to organizations that allocate at least 90% of income to school scholarships for eligible students. The credit is subject to limitations based on the taxpayer's regular tax and tentative minimum tax for the year. Controlled groups are treated as one taxpayer for this purpose, and taxpayers can elect to not apply the credit for a taxable year. The tax code provides a credit for contributions benefiting elementary and secondary schools, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. Additionally, a new credit is introduced for elementary and secondary school teachers who provide classroom materials. An eligible educator can claim a tax credit for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses up to $1,000. Eligible educators are defined as teachers, instructors, counselors, principals, or aides who work at least 900 hours in a school year. Qualified expenses include books, supplies, computer equipment, and supplementary materials used in the classroom. The tax credit for qualified education expenses is subject to special rules, including the denial of double benefits and limitations on the credit amount based on the taxpayer's regular tax and tentative minimum tax. Taxpayers can also elect to not apply this credit for a taxable year. The tax credit for elementary and secondary school teachers providing classroom materials is effective for taxable years after December 31, 2001. Adjusted gross income considers professional development expenses for these teachers. The tax code amendment allows eligible educators to deduct up to $1,500 for professional development expenses related to their teaching subjects. The program must be approved by the local educational agency. The amendment to the tax code allows educators to deduct professional development expenses exceeding certain limits, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001.
